channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ukraine Live Updates: Russia Intensifies Shelling in the East, Signaling Its Next Offensive
item.description: With one province in the Donbas region under their control, Russian forces have ramped up the shelling of cities in the other province, Donetsk.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times

item.title: ‘Get the Stretcher!’ Life and Death on Ukraine’s Front Line
item.description: On another day of scorched-earth artillery barrages in the east, a team of Ukrainian medics did their best to stabilize and assure the survivors, with the din of war all around.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Natalia Yermak and Tyler Hicks
item.media:credit: Tyler Hicks/The New York Times

item.title: Why So Many British Workers Are On Strike
item.description: With energy costs and inflation surging, and taxes and the cost of loans increasing, British workers are demanding higher pay and going on strike with a militancy not seen in years.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Carl Court/Getty Images
item.media:description: Lawyers protesting last week in London outside the Central Criminal Court, also known as the Old Bailey.

item.title: El Salvador’s Bitcoin Bet Isn’t Paying Off
item.description: It brought El Salvador’s president, Nayib Bukele, the adulation of the tech community, but reduced scarce funds and moved the nation closer to default.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Bryan Avelar
item.media:credit: Jose Cabezas/Reuters
item.media:description: President Nayib Bukele of El Salvador at an event in June to mark his third year in office.

item.title: Palestinian Outrage After U.S. Says Journalist Was Killed by Accident
item.description: The U.S. government said Shireen Abu Akleh was likely hit by a bullet fired from Israeli military lines in the occupied West Bank, but unintentionally, fueling claims that Washington isn’t impartial.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Abbas Momani
item.media:description: Colleagues and friends react as the Palestinian flag-draped body of the veteran Al Jazeera journalist Shireen Abu Akleh is brought to the news channel’s office in the West Bank city of Ramallah in May.

item.title: Young Politicians Seek Change, but Face Hurdles as Old as Politics
item.description: A new law allowed a record number of young people to run in local elections this year. But they face skepticism, cultural hurdles and problems as old as politics itself.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Cheon Seung-ah, 19, second from left, at a gathering organized by the Korea Women Parliamentarian Network in Seoul last month. In June, she became the youngest election winner in South Korea’s history.

item.title: Has Biden’s Top Diplomat in Mexico, Ken Salazar, Gone Too Far, Officials Ask?
item.description: Administration officials fear that the U.S. ambassador’s cozy relationship with the Mexican president has backfired, and may be setting back American interests in the region.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff and Maria Abi-Habib
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ken Salazar, the American ambassador to Mexico, at his official residence in Mexico City.

item.title: Xiao Jianhua, Chinese Canadian Billionaire, on Trial in China
item.description: The case against the financier Xiao Jianhua is widely seen as part of a crackdown on the debt-fueled excess that drove China’s economic growth.
item.dc:creator: Amy Qin
item.media:credit: The New York Times
item.media:description: Xiao Jianhua in Beijing in an undated photograph. He has not been heard from since he was taken out of Hong Kong under mysterious circumstances in January 2017.

item.title: Bullet Too Damaged to Prove Who Killed Shireen Abu Akleh, U.S. Says
item.description: The State Department said Shireen Abu Akleh, the Al Jazeera broadcaster killed in the West Bank in May, was likely hit by shots fired from Israeli military positions.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Lara Jakes
item.media:credit: Samar Hazboun for The New York Times

item.title: Pope Francis Dispels Rumors He’s About to Retire
item.description: Benedict’s exit changed expectations that the papacy would always be a lifetime assignment, fueling speculation the current pope has tried to push away.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Remo Casilli/Reuters
item.media:description: Pope Francis leading Mass at the Vatican this month. He has often left open the possibility of one day resigning if declining health made it impossible for him to run the Roman Catholic Church.

item.title: Nazi Tapes Provide a Chilling Sequel to the Eichmann Trial
item.description: Sixty years after the execution of Adolf Eichmann, the logistics chief of the Holocaust, an Israeli documentary airs his confessions in his own voice.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.category: The Devil's Confession: The Lost Eichmann Tapes (TV Program)
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Images from the 1961 trial of Adolf Eichmann at an exhibition in Jerusalem in June. A documentary, “The Devil’s Confession,” has aired recordings unheard during the proceedings.

item.title: Where the Risks of Pregnancy Meet Abortion Laws and Health Care
item.description: Even before the wave of abortion bans, medical treatment and advice for pregnancy has largely focused on fetal safety over the mother’s.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:credit: Rogelio V. Solis/Associated Press
item.media:description: A midwife at a clinic in Jackson, Miss., using a handheld probe to measure a fetal heartbeat.

item.title: Russia Advances Behind Brutal Barrage, but Will Its Strategy Keep Working?
item.description: The Russian and Ukrainian armies have both been badly mauled, raising questions about how long they can keep fighting as they have, particularly the outgunned Ukrainians.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.media:credit: Tyler Hicks/The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers in Lysychansk last month. The city has since been taken by Russian forces.

item.title: In Putin’s Russia, the Arrests Are Spreading Quickly and Widely
item.description: One by one, Russians deemed insufficiently patriotic are being snatched up by security forces as the Kremlin tightens the noose.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Dmitry Serebryakov/Associated Press
item.media:description: Vladimir Mau, a detained academic official, being shielded by his lawyer at a court hearing in Moscow last month.

item.title: Boris Johnson Fights to Hold Power After 2 Top Ministers Jump Ship
item.description: Two top cabinet members resigned from the scandal-scarred British prime minister’s government. Some wondered if the master of political survival could pull off another save.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Justin Tallis
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson at at a cabinet meeting Tuesday with Sajid Javid, left, then the health secretary, and Rishi Sunak, third from the right, then the chancellor of the Exchequer.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Russia’s Next Offensive
item.description: Plus Boris Johnson’s fight for political survival and Twitter’s lawsuit against India
item.dc:creator: Whet Moser
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sloviansk was hit by shelling on Tuesday as Russia set its sights on Donetsk.

item.title: As Russia Moves on Another Province, Ukrainians Leave Ghost Towns Behind
item.description: Vast stretches of eastern Ukraine are now largely devoid of people and industry. If Ukraine is ever to have a vibrant postwar future, it is unlikely to sprout from these ruins.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer, Maria Varenikova and The New York Times
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nina Zakharenko being evacuated from her home in Bakhmut.

item.title: Who Is Chris Pincher?
item.description: Chris Pincher’s actions could easily have gone unnoticed if Boris Johnson’s government hadn’t already been troubled.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Thierry Monasse/Getty Images
item.media:description: Chris Pincher, a British lawmaker, at a European Union meeting in Brussels in 2020, when he was a minister in the Foreign Office.

item.title: Who Is Rishi Sunak?
item.description: Boris Johnson appointed Mr. Sunak chancellor, the government’s chief financial officer and often second in power only to the prime minister, in February 2020.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Oli Scarff
item.media:description: Rishi Sunak arriving for a regional cabinet meeting in Stoke-on-Trent, England, in May.

item.title: U.S. Aims to Expand Export Bans on China Over Security and Human Rights
item.description: The Biden administration is applying lessons learned from controls on Russia during the Ukraine war to try to limit China’s military and technological advances.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Ana Swanson
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden and his aides call China the greatest long-term rival of the United States, surpassing Russia.

item.title: France Brings Home French Wives of ISIS Jihadists From Syria
item.description: The country repatriated 16 women from Syria, in a move it had long ruled out. Thirty-five children, including some orphans, accompanied them.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Al Hol detention camp in northeastern Syria in 2019. France had long resisted calls to repatriate adult women, saying that it considered them “fighters” who should be tried in Syria and Iraq.

item.title: Covid Outbreak Emerges in China’s Anhui Province
item.description: The country recently began to recover from a surge that shut down Shanghai for two months.
item.dc:creator: Zixu Wang
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Coronavirus testing on Monday in Anhui Province.

item.title: A Bluer Picture
item.description: The midterm campaigns for the House and the Senate are shaping up quite differently.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senate Democrats are starting to see the opportunity to retain the Senate after the midterms.

item.title: Reduced Testing and Reporting Blur Covid Picture in U.S.
item.description: As states report less frequently, changes in the trajectory of the virus are slower to reveal themselves.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan and Sarah Cahalan
item.media:credit: Veasey Conway for The New York Times
item.media:description: A coronavirus testing site in Durham, N.C., in May. The vast majority of positive results from popular home test kits are not included in official data, and not everyone who gets infected knows or gets tested.

item.title: U.S. veterans are training Ukrainians near the front lines in the fight against Russia.
item.dc:creator: Dave Philipps
item.media:credit: Zack Wittman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Perry Blackburn Jr., a retired Army Special Forces lieutenant colonel who spent 34 years in uniform, last month at his home in Tampa, Fla. He has been in Ukraine training soldiers on combat.

item.title: Ukraine’s prime minister says rebuilding will cost $750 billion.
item.description: World leaders are mapping out the monumental effort to restore a war-battered nation.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky and Nick Cumming-Bruce
item.media:credit: Fabrice Coffrini/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine speaking via video link to attendants of a conference in Lugano, Switzerland, on Monday.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Russia’s tightening grip in the Donbas.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: The downtown Highland Park area where a gunman opened fire yesterday.

item.title: Zhang Sizhi, Lawyer Who Defended Chinese Dissidents, Dies at 94
item.description: He shed tears over the challenge of defending clients in a system stacked against them. But even in defeat, admirers said, he set a lasting example.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley and Joy Dong

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: A Mass Shooting Near Chicago
item.description: Plus Russia regroups in the east and China arrests a mysterious tycoon.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Nam Y. Huh/Associated Press
item.media:description: Law enforcement searched in Highland Park, Ill., after a mass shooting at the Highland Park Fourth of July parade on Monday.

item.title: A spate of arrests suggests the Kremlin is further clamping down on dissent.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Dmitry Serebryakov/Associated Press
item.media:description: Vladimir Mau, a detained academic official, being shielded by his lawyer at a court hearing in Moscow last month.

item.title: French President Macron Adjusts His Cabinet, Seeking a Fresh Start
item.description: The new appointments by President Emmanuel Macron of France are unlikely to help him push his agenda through a fragmented lower house of Parliament.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: International diplomacy has been the priority of late for President Emmanuel Macron of France, center, with President Biden at the Group of 7 summit last month.

item.title: Chosen Families
item.description: Spending the holiday with those who support you.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: A Refreshing Look at Egypt’s Ancient Pyramids
item.description: A downpour, a dust storm and an encounter with a lively dig team offered a photographer a new perspective on the country’s celebrated tombs.
item.dc:creator: Tanveer Badal
item.media:credit: Tanveer Badal
item.media:description: Tourists brace for cover as the sand storm approaches at the six-tiered Step Pyramid of Djoser.

item.title: Are Covid Vaccines That Defend Against Omicron Variants Too Late?
item.description: The government has greenlit new vaccines to defend against the latest Omicron variants. But the shots won’t arrive until the fall, and cases are rising now.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mueller
item.media:credit: Erika P. Rodriguez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A booster dose being administered in San Juan, P.R. The F.D.A. has asked vaccine manufacturers to tailor new booster shots to the most evasive Omicron subvariants yet, BA.4 and BA.5.

item.title: Copenhagen Mall Shooting: Police See No Terrorism Motive
item.description: The suspect in the attack that killed 3 people was known to mental health services, the police said, and the victims appeared to be random.
item.dc:creator: Jasmina Nielsen, Emma Bubola and Euan Ward
item.media:credit: EPA-EFE, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: People outside Fields shopping center in Copenhagen, where a shooting took place on Sunday.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: A Russian assault on eastern Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers in Donetsk on Thursday.

item.title: In Ukraine, U.S. Veterans Step In Where the Military Will Not
item.description: Special Operations veterans are training Ukrainians near the front lines in the fight against Russia, despite warnings from the Pentagon.
item.dc:creator: Dave Philipps
item.media:credit: Zack Wittman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Perry Blackburn Jr., who recently returned from Ukraine, organized supplies last month as he prepared for his next trip to the country.

item.title: Australia’s Prime Minister Promises More Aid During Ukraine Visit
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelensky described the visit as the first by an Australian prime minister to his country during their history of diplomatic relations.
item.dc:creator: Alex Traub
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Nariman El-Mofty/Associated Press
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine, right, with the Australian prime minister, Anthony Albanese, during a press conference, in Kyiv, Ukraine, on Sunday.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: Russia Seizes Lysychansk
item.description: Plus a heat wave engulfs Japan and transgender activists in Pakistan debate protections.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: A woman touched the portrait of late Ukrainian soldier Anatoly Mykolayovych Potaychuk, 40, inside the church before going to the cemetery for burial during a funeral ceremony in Babyntsi, in Ukraine, on Saturday.

item.title: Lysychansk, Ukraine’s Last Outpost in Luhansk, Falls to Russia
item.description: Lysychansk managed to hold out for a week after its twin city, Sievierodonetsk, was captured. But on Sunday a pro-Russian flag flew there, as well.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Kamila Hrabchuk and Vivian Yee
item.media:credit: Tyler Hicks/The New York Times
item.media:description: Lysychansk, Ukraine, last month. Russia subjected the city to prolonged bombardment.

item.title: At Least 7 Die in Glacier Collapse in Italy’s Dolomites
item.description: The glacier has been shrinking for years, and climate change contributed to the tragedy, Italy’s prime minister said. Fourteen people are missing.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Alpine Rescue Services, via Reuters

item.title: Three Dead in Denmark After Shooting in Copenhagen Mall
item.description: The police said that one person was in custody but that it was too early to suggest a motive for the shooting, which happened at the Field’s shopping center on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: Vimal Patel and Jasmina Nielsen
item.media:credit: Ritzau Scanpix/Via Reuters
item.media:description: Terrified shoppers fled for safety after a gunman opened fire at a mall in Copenhagen on Sunday, leaving three people dead and at least three others critically wounded.

item.title: Why the City of Lysychansk Is a Big Prize in Putin’s War Strategy
item.description: Controlling the cities of Sievierodonetsk and Lysychansk means Russia could position its forces to mount offensives on cities to the southwest.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Smoke rose above the Ukrainian cities of Lysychansk and Sievierodonetsk after heavy Russian bombardment last month.

item.title: Russia appears to be taking steps toward two industrial cities.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: An unexploded Russian rocket protruding out of the pavement in Lysychansk, Ukraine, last month.

item.title: Behind the Scenes of the Supreme Court
item.description: Getting a sense of the mood after a momentous term.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Anna Rose Layden for The New York Times
item.media:description: Climate activists gather at the Supreme Court in Washington, D.C., following the ruling of the court on West Virginia v. EPA on Thursday.

item.title: What Are the Abortion Laws in Countries Around the World?
item.description: The U.S. Supreme Court’s ruling on abortion quickly led to bans in at least eight states, a shift toward criminalization that runs counter to recent easings in countries that had longstanding bans.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Shuran Huang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Activists clashing outside the U.S. Supreme Court on June 27, days after it eliminated the constitutional right to abortion. The ruling contrasted with recent decisions by high courts in Mexico and Colombia, which have moved to decriminalize abortion.

item.title: In Northern Ireland, Brexit and Legislation Revive Old Challenges
item.description: Brexit and so-called legacy legislation are reviving sensitive issues of Catholic and Protestant identity that civic leaders have sought to dampen.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Peace Bridge, which opened in 2011, connects the Catholic and Protestant sides of Derry, Northern Ireland.

item.title: Big Ben Bongs Will Soon Ring Out Again Across London
item.description: Next to the Houses of Parliament, the tower that houses the enormous bell has been undergoing renovation since 2017.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Elizabeth Tower, called the Clock Tower until it was renamed in 2012, has been refurbished at a cost of about $97 million.

item.title: Women who were raped by Russian soldiers yearn for justice.
item.description: Rapes were among the many atrocities Russian troops inflicted on Ukrainian civilians during weeks of occupation in the Kyiv suburbs and elsewhere. But the challenges of prosecuting the assaults are daunting.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Viktoriya and a neighbor were raped by Russian soldiers, who also killed two men, including her neighbor’s husband.

item.title: Four Killed After Explosions in a Russian City Near the Ukraine Border
item.description: The Russians said its air-defense systems shot down three missiles, but one fell to the ground in central Belgorod.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Austin Ramzy
item.media:credit: Vasily Maximov/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The Russian city of Belgorod in 2019.

item.title: Investigators of War Crimes in Ukraine Face Formidable Challenges
item.description: International agencies are joining Ukrainian prosecutors in what may be the biggest effort ever to hold war criminals to account. But the difficulties and dangers they face are exceptional, too.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A witness to the death of Oleksiy Ketler standing over his coffin.

item.title: Palestinians Give U.S. Bullet That Killed Shireen Abu Akleh
item.description: Officials believe that the bullet, which killed Shireen Abu Akleh, could hold essential clues as to who is responsible for her death.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Samar Hazboun for The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial at the site where Shireen Abu Akleh was killed in the West Bank.

item.title: In Estonia, Ethnic Russians Start Questioning Putin’s War
item.description: Narva, in northeastern Estonia, is the E.U.’s most ethnically Russian city, with a population supportive of President Vladimir Putin. But the conflict in Ukraine has set off a “mental war” between old and young.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Marta Giaccone for The New York Times
item.media:description: The bridge over the Narva River that separates Ivangorod, Russia, from Narva, Estonia. Some ethnic Russians in Narva are starting to doubt the Kremlin’s official narrative about the war in Ukraine.

item.title: The fight for the last city in Luhansk under Ukrainian control reaches a pivotal point.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Natalia Yermak
item.media:credit: Anatolii Stepanov/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: After weeks of heavy fighting in Lysychansk and its surroundings, Ukrainian forces appeared to be pulling back from the city as Russian troops threatened to surround it.

item.title: Lesia Tsurenko Plays Tennis to Earn Money to Help Ukraine
item.description: She used to compete because she loved tennis, but now Tsurenko wants to win as much prize money as possible to help people in her war-torn country.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Futterman

item.title: Russia Steps Up Pace of Missile Attacks on Civilian Targets
item.description: The Russians’ growing use of imprecise Soviet-era missiles to terrorize civilians reflects the daunting outlook of its offensive despite incremental gains, analysts say.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins, Anatoly Kurmanaev and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Russian missile strike Friday on a nine-story apartment building in Serhiivka, in the Odesa region of Ukraine, killed at least 21 people.

item.title: This regional leader is a symbol of Ukrainian defiance.
item.description: Vitaliy Kim is the head of the regional military administration in the embattled southern city of Mykolaiv.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vitaliy Kim has worked to puncture the legend of Russia’s might. “It was important to convey that the enemy was not as scary as it seemed, and to tell the world that we are here, that we exist,” he said.

item.title: His Union Went on Strike. His Interviews Went Viral.
item.description: At a time of rampant inflation and wage stagnation, Mick Lynch, the force behind Britain’s largest railway strikes in three decades, has found success that has surprised even his colleagues.
item.dc:creator: Saskia Solomon
item.category: National Union of Rail, Maritime and Transport Workers (RMT)
item.media:credit: Saskia Solomon/The New York Times
item.media:description: Mick Lynch, the general secretary of the National Union of Rail, Maritime and Transport Workers, has used a series of combative television interviews to build public support for the union.

item.title: In Pakistan, a Leader in Trans Rights, Reality Is Slower to Change Than Law
item.description: Four years after the country became one of the few to protect transgender people’s rights in statute, violence against them has surged and discrimination remains common.
item.dc:creator: Zia ur-Rehman
item.media:credit: Saiyna Bashir for The New York Times
item.media:description: A transgender woman known as Madam Kashish begging for money in May in Karachi, Pakistan. It is difficult for many in the transgender community in Pakistan to find jobs.

item.title: Brittney Griner’s Detention in Moscow Is Latest in Hostage Diplomacy
item.description: The United States believes the charges against the basketball star are spurious and tied to American support of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Max Fisher
item.media:credit: Kirill Kudryavtsev/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Brittney Griner, center, arriving for a court hearing on Friday outside Moscow.
